Posts.Content: Jul 31, 2012 07:55AM akc820608 wrote: 44andscared, I understand how you feel.  My aunt died August 2011 of metastatic BC.  No family history.  Two month and a week after she died, my doctor found a lump.  Turned out to be a complex cyst, which they aspirated.  At my 6 month follow up, they found another growth in the same area as first.  Had that biopsied and excised.  This time it was intraductal papillomatosis with atypia.  I go back again in 5 months.  I am 29.  I have found nothing to really calm my fears other than keeping myself busy with my kids.  Hope everything turns out benign!!

Posts.Content: Aug 28, 2012 01:51AM akc820608 wrote: I just wanted to say thank you for starting this thread.  Wasn't sure where on Stage IV to write this.  I had an aunt pass away last year, and a friend in January.  Both diagnosed with stage IV from the get go.  I was so aftaid I would say the wrong things, but wasn't sure what to say.  I didn't want to always have a pitty face, but wanted them to know I cared.  I have read other threads on the stage IV forum and it has helped me to understand how they felt.  Now, I will use this knowledge with the others I know that have cancer.  So thank you to everyone for your point of view.

Posts.Content: akc820608 wrote: Well the good nees is my excisional was benign. The crappy news is my biopsy said intraductal papillomatosis with atypia and the surgical said no intraductal pap w any atypia. Also on the same report a paragraph above said papilloma. I told my doctor none of that made sense and he agreed. He said he would speak to the pathologist. I told him my symptoms came back 2 says after surgery along with nipple discharge. And the best part of it all is he didn't want to do an MRI because more spots may show up that could be benign. Just come back in 6 months for US. I was very upset. What do you all think? Oh, also said I am high risk but would just US every 6 months. Grrr... Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 02:58PM akc820608 wrote: I wouldn't be concerned until you get the biopsy done and something shows a reason to be concerned.  Just stay on top of everything and try to ask your doc the questions.  Of course, I always forget to ask certain questions until I get home. :)  Until your biopsy, this is a good place to be.  Best of luck!
Posts.Title: Waiting to schedule biopsy.... LuvSnow pamelahope

Posts.Content: Aug 6, 2012 01:08PM akc820608 wrote: Nurseash85, I had a biopsy after an US found something a few months ago. Pathology came back as intraductal papillomatiosis with mild atypia.  Had an excisional afterwards.  I asked the doctor if we could do an MRI, he said he didn't want to because other benign areas may show up.....  That sounded silly to me and my GP.  After fighting with the insurance company for a while, I am finally getting one.  Also, after the excisional, my sypmtoms never got better. In the end, just make sure you are happy.  If you don't like what is going on, get a second opinion.  It is your body, not the doctor's.  Good luck! :-)
